1.words: Okay. Now, I'll start facilitating an intentional type of conversation, so I'm sharing personal stories and experiences rather than positions on issues. The MIT group designing this conversation is finding that this approach helps build connections and deepen mutual understanding. Before we begin, let's review some conversation agreements, including some baseline agreements. We're not on Zoom today, so I'll just say them out loud. If you disagree or you want to add anything to these conversation agreements, let me know. Speak for yourself and on your own experience. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time. Take turns and allow others to finish speaking. Stay curious. Ask honest questions. Pause. Take time for reflection. Listen generously. Assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. Show that you're listening actively. Head nods, eye contact, and reactions in the chat help show people you are paying close attention to them. Close distractions on your laptop or phone to pay attention to each other as much as possible. Is everyone on board with these guidelines?

1.linked_words: Is everyone on board with these guidelines?

20.words: Me personally, I've never experienced anything like that, but I thought that watching that video made me really think about how I get on a plane pretty often I'd say, at least three times a year. And it never really crosses my mind how scary that could be, but watching that and knowing that I'm actually going to be traveling on an Alaskan Airlines plane recently, it makes me a little bit more concerned about the possibilities of flights that could happen around me or to people that I know.

30.words: All right, I'll talk about a story that didn't affect me directly either, but it was difficult talking about in a specific situation, which was a little while ago, maybe a year or so ago, I had an opportunity, a very unique opportunity to fly on a private jet. However, when talking about the opportunity with my parents, they brought up a story of their friend who had flown on a private jet about 20 years or so ago and he passed away in an accident on that plane. That personally affected them as he was one of their very close friends. That affected them on a very deep level, but it also created a sense of fear, which was difficult for them to talk about to me directly. One, because it hurt them to talk about losing their friend, but also because they don't want to take away from something from me, but they also want to protect me, and I think looking about that situation, it can be seen as one in a million or one in a hundred thousand of situations that occur like that, but the fact is that there is still that risk and that's just a difficult thing to talk about, and especially once it's related to someone and it can be a difficult thing for you to warn someone about even when it's not that common.

47.words: I definitely think my view on flying in airlines definitely changed, especially when thinking about how Boeing didn't necessarily take the best safety precautions going into the flight and how I might now think twice when getting on a plane or maybe be a little bit more skeptical every time I go on a plane now because as Ryland said earlier, we go on planes all the time, gone on three this year and I just hopped on and didn't really think twice when I got on the plane. But now, the fact that there's been a series of incidents with Boeing and how it is not guaranteed to make it to the other side safely, that might definitely make me think twice before getting on a plane.
